title: 105_hr4398
content:
The "Women's Progress Commemoration Act" declares the establishment of a Federal Commission to preserve historic sites significant to American women's history, in honor of the Seneca Falls Convention of 1848. The "Women's Progress Commemoration Commission" is established with 15 members appointed by various leaders in government based on their knowledge or expertise. The "Women's Progress Commemoration Commission" is established with 15 members appointed based on their knowledge or expertise in relevant matters. Members can come from various sectors and backgrounds to ensure diversity in economic, professional, and cultural representation. The appointment process involves consultation with key government leaders. The President, Speaker of the House of Representatives, and Senate leaders consult to appoint members of the Commission for fair representation of diverse viewpoints. Appointments must be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission must hold its initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. Subsequent meetings will be called by the Chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for business transactions, with the ability for a lesser number to hold hearings. The Commission will select a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. The Commission must select a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members. The Commission, in collaboration with relevant entities, must identify historical sites significant to the women's movement and recommend actions for their preservation and public education under the National Historic Preservation Act. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence to carry out its duties. It can also obtain necessary information from Federal agencies. Additionally, the Commission's personnel matters are addressed in Section 6. (a) Compensation of Members.--A member of the Commission who is not an officer or employee of the Federal Government shall be compensated at a rate equal to the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay prescribed for a position at level IV of the Executive Schedule. A member who is a government officer or employee shall serve without additional compensation. 
(b) Travel Expenses.--Members are allowed travel expenses, including per diem, at authorized rates while away from home. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The executive director's compensation should not exceed the rate for a position at level V of the Executive Schedule. Other personnel's compensation can be determined by the Chairperson without restrictions. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. Other personnel's compensation can be determined without restrictions. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson may procure temporary and intermittent services as needed. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and staff without civil service laws. Compensation for personnel can be set at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual pay for a position at level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 7. FUNDING: Appropriations authorized for Commission operations. Donations from non-Federal sources accepted. SEC. 8. TERMINATION: Commission ends 30 days after report submission to Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 9. REPORTS TO CONGRESS: Interior Secretary to report to Congress on actions taken to preserve historical sites identified by the Commission.
